relationships.evidence_text: Thea is Executive Director of the Biodynamic Association, bringing vitality and renewal to the food system through regenerative agriculture.
She lives in the Mayacamas Mountains in Sonoma County, California, on land originally steward by Lake Miwok, Pomow, and Wago people.
Since 2011, Thea has played a key role in developing the Biodynamic Association's programs and exploring new ways to manage and evolve the organization.

relationships.target: diversified organic and biodynamic production farming
relationships.evidence_text: Her previous experience includes diversified organic and biodynamic production farming.

evidence.target_surface: diversified organic and biodynamic production farming

relationships.evidence_text: Thea holds a Bachelor of Science in Earth Systems from Stanford University.
and a Permaculture Design Certificate from Occidental Arts and Ecology Center.
She is also a graduate of the Coaching Fellowship and the Center for Courage and Renewals Academy for Leaders.
She is a leader, facilitator, educator, and farmer dedicated to building living soil, growing nutritious food, and nurturing vibrant communities.

Biodynamics is important to me personally for a lot of reasons, but I think one of the things that is most important to me about it is it offers a positive pathway for me to be in relationship with the Earth and contributing to a positive future for the planet.
biodynamics is a holistic and ecological and ethical approach to agriculture and land stewardship.
It started in Europe in the 1920s and has been brought to every continent.
It can be practiced in every climate and every scale.
it's really based on this idea of nurturing each farmer garden as a living organism.
that generates abundance for the people and also helps to bring health and healing to the land.
this is part of the work we're doing in our community mobilization efforts through the Y on Earth community.
I studied Earth Systems and College and came from this, you know, environmental stewardship lens.
I'm so excited to have this opportunity to dive into the realm of biodynamics with you today.
to talk about some really exciting ways that our audience can engage in a huge event coming up in November.
it offers a positive pathway for me to be in relationship with the Earth.
biodynamics really offers, I feel a way to constantly deepen and learn and find ways to contribute to healing and renewal and vitality for myself and my community and the Earth.
the compost pile has a particular function similar to an organ in our body having a particular function.

the core of our kind of gardening farming activities is about 13 acres of that land.
we're stewarding the whole thing as a whole.
we have goats in there eating branches from the trees that are outside the pasture.

after it's composted goes on to our vegetable beds.
we're really working to integrate all the different elements.
